title: Adenophyllum porophylloides
text:
Adenophyllum porophylloides is a species of flowering plant in the <a href="Asteraceae">daisy family</a> known by the common names San Felipe dogweed and San Felipe dyssodia. It is native to the <a href="Sonoran%20Desert">Sonoran</a> and <a href="Mojave%20Desert">Mojave Desert</a>s of the southwestern <a href="United%20States">United States</a> (<a href="Arizona">Arizona</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, <a href="Nevada">Nevada</a>) and northwestern <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a> (<a href="Sonora">Sonora</a>, <a href="Baja%20California">Baja California</a>, <a href="Baja%20California%20Sur">Baja California Sur</a>).
"Adenophyllum porophylloides" is an aromatic desert subshrub with several branching stems reaching a maximum height near 60 centimeters. The sparse, clawlike leaves are divided into sharply pointed linear lobes that bear prominent resin glands. The foliage has an unpleasant scent. The <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a> is borne on a <a href="Peduncle%20%28botany%29">peduncle</a> several centimeters long. The <a href="Head%20%28botany%29">flower head</a> is cylindrical and lined with <a href="Bract">phyllaries</a> with large resin glands on them. The tip of the head blooms with bright yellow to reddish orange disc florets. There are sometimes short, stubby yellow to reddish ray florets along the rim. The fruit is an <a href="achene">achene</a> about 5 millimeters long with a bristly, scaly <a href="Pappus%20%28flower%20structure%29">pappus</a>.
